captions.text:
We are in Torrejón de Ardoz,
near Madrid,

and this is a championship called
Red Bull Skate Arcade.

It's a sort of championship
that emulates a video game

where you have to make your way
through screens and levels.

I'm very lucky, because there's only
about a thousand skaters
who came and sent in videos.
I'm one of the 20 finalists,

and I came to enjoy the weekend
with all my colleagues
and to skate.
♪ (8-bit music) ♪
(applause from crowd)
♪ (electronic music) ♪
(cheering and applause from crowd)
♪ (music and cheering continue) ♪
(cheering and hooting)
Well, competition has been stiff.

Every time I tried to do a trick,
i couldn't make it.

Suddenly I heard the crowd shouting,
cheering others on with their tricks,
or maybe I saw how they did it, and wow!
That gave me the strength to say,

"I've got to do my own thing
and make it to the top, and win."
♪ (8-bit music) ♪

title: Skateboarding contest in Spain - Red Bull Skate Arcade 2014

comments.author: Daniel Pattrick

comments.text:
+sem b It's a moronic question because whether you agree with their 
decision or not, it's obvious why they don't wear helmets. They've decided 
the risk (not the same as certainty) of head injury is worth it because 
they don't like the way it looks, the way it is perceived, or how it feels 
(or any combination thereof). It's not as if they've never heard of helmets 
and aren't aware of the benefits. You make thinking seem like it's really 
difficult.
comments.author: SB Account

comments.text:

comments.text:
Why would it be a moronic question if I ask why the pro's don't wear 
helmets?
And if you say my English isn't good cuz of 1 or 2 little (you'll probably

English and didn't got English class at school, I think I'm doing a pretty 
good job :)
But let's all go ahead and not make this a big point...

Bye guys :)
